Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor has set aside open office hours throughout the week.
Situation2: They notice a minor ethical dilemma at work, like someone cutting in line, and feel a mild urge to act.
Story: I sat outside my mentor’s office, waiting for my turn during her open hours. The hallway was quiet except for the low hum of conversation from inside. I glanced at my watch, rehearsing the questions I wanted to ask, determined not to waste her time. Just then, I noticed a colleague slip ahead of me, pretending not to see the line. My heart thudded. As a Hindu, I was taught to stand up for what’s right, even in small matters. But as a mentee, I didn’t want to cause a scene or disrupt the flow of my mentor’s carefully scheduled time. I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me—one urging me to speak up, the other to stay silent and respectful. My palms grew clammy as I wrestled with what to do, caught between honoring my mentor’s time and my own sense of dharma.
